rationale: Per proper noun usage and brand standards, the company name is “JPMorgan Chase Foundation” (no space between JP and Morgan). Ensures accuracy and professionalism.

original_text: Appendix B: Profiles of Lower-Potential States
suggested_edit: Appendix B: Profiles of Lower Potential States
rationale: Bellwether style discourages unnecessary hyphenation in compound modifiers when clarity is maintained; similar headings elsewhere omit the hyphen (e.g., “High-Potential States” is used as a section title but here consistency within appendices is preferable). Choose one treatment throughout; recommend no hyphen for readability.
AP/Bellwether generally avoid hyphens with phrasal ranges when used as nouns (not modifiers). “Near term” and “mid term” function as nouns here.

original_text: Distill lessons regarding the role of philanthropy to identify what might be replicable strategies elsewhere
suggested_edit: Distill lessons regarding the role of philanthropy to identify strategies that might be replicable elsewhere
rationale: Improves clarity and word order; maintains Bellwether’s concise, active tone.
Bellwether/AP style spells out numbers one through nine in narrative text.
There appears to be an extra space after “the” in the heading (“12 of the 26”) in the graphic. Ensure consistent spacing in headings.

original_text: After the second phase of research and interviews,* 5 states emerged...
suggested_edit: After the second phase of research and interviews, five states emerged... (A list of interviewees is included in Appendix A.)
rationale: Avoids dangling asterisk in body text; spell out numbers one through nine; move explanatory note into parentheses to improve readability in a client deliverable.

original_text: States have already adopted an OBF-focused policy and are moving into implementation and evaluation of that policy.
suggested_edit: States have already adopted an OBF-focused policy and are moving into that policy’s implementation and evaluation.
rationale: Reduces repetition and improves flow while keeping original meaning.

original_text: Georgia does not have outcomes-based funding. Its current formula is 25 years old and based on enrollment by type of program.
suggested_edit: Georgia does not have outcomes-based funding. Its current formula, 25 years old, is based on enrollment by type of program.
rationale: Improves readability by setting off the age as a nonessential phrase and fixes sentence structure.
Per Bellwether exceptions, spell out acronyms on first use for reader clarity.
Potential misspelling of the executive director of Achieve Atlanta’s first name. Please verify; if current spelling is correct, disregard.

AP style abbreviates state names in running text as “Pa.” when used as a stand-in for the state. However, this document often uses postal abbreviations (e.g., GA, AL). Choose one approach and apply consistently; for client deliverables, consistency is the priority.
Confirm consistent presentation of “N/A” across tables; some tables use “None” or em dashes. Recommend standardizing to one convention (e.g., em dash) for clarity.
Spell out numbers one through nine when they are part of a compound modifier.

original_text: about 10% of community colleges’ operations funding
suggested_edit: about 10% of community colleges’ operations funding
rationale: AP now allows %; usage here is correct. Ensure consistent use of numerals and percent signs throughout; earlier pages mix words and symbols.

original_text: There is a mismatch between demand and supply in the labor market: Most jobs in the state (58%) require some postsecondary education but not a degree, but only 47% of Alabamians have this training.
suggested_edit: There is a mismatch between demand and supply in the labor market: Most jobs in the state (58%) require some postsecondary education but not a degree, while only 47% of Alabamians have this training.
rationale: Replaces repetitive “but” construction; improves readability.
AP style abbreviates state names in titles; use “Ala.” not postal code in narrative or titles. Apply similarly to “AL Rep.” below if consistent with chosen convention.
Capitalize only the first word and proper nouns in act names per AP style.
AP style takes an extra s after singular proper names ending in s unless the next word begins with s; “Arkansas’s” is preferred.
AP omits periods in most academic degrees (JD, PhD). Ensure consistency across the document.

original_text: Ohio’s formula is 100% outcomes-based and includes rates calculated using average statewide costs, disaggregation by program type, and adjustments for underserved students.
suggested_edit: Ohio’s formula is 100% outcomes-based and includes rates calculated using average statewide costs, disaggregated by program type, with adjustments for underserved students.
rationale: Improves parallel structure and readability.
AP style spells out “million” rather than using “M.”
Ensure consistent hyphenation of compound modifiers; usage here is correct. Check other instances (e.g., “under-prepared/at-risk”) for consistency.

issue: Link style and punctuation inside quotes
rationale: If the item is a live link, avoid ending punctuation inside the hyperlink per common formatting conventions; ensure period is outside link. If not linked, leave as is.

original_text: State Higher Education Executive Officers Association
suggested_edit: State Higher Education Executive Officers Association (SHEEO)
rationale: First mention should introduce widely used acronym if used elsewhere; verify later use. Improves clarity for funder audience.
Verify if both are from Texas 2036; if listing two names for one organization, consider separate rows for clarity. As-is is grammatically fine; flagging for potential table consistency.
Use an en dash for year ranges per AP/Bellwether formatting in narrative; ensure consistency across slides (e.g., FY26–27, SY23–24).

suggested_edit: Momentum Points: not clearly defined in statute or guidance
rationale: Clarifies what is unclear without adding new content; maintains professional tone.
Capitalize metric labels consistently within tables when other metric names appear in title case (e.g., “Progression,” “Transfers”). Ensure uniform style across all tables.
AP style typically uses ’s after singular proper nouns ending in s; apply consistently unless following an internal exception.

original_text: MA may be using an OBF formula, but the details are unclear
suggested_edit: Massachusetts may be using an outcomes-based funding (OBF) formula, but the details are unclear
rationale: Spell out state names and terms on first mention for clarity; then introduce abbreviation per Bellwether exceptions and AP style.
Remove stray space after hyphen; compound modifiers before nouns should be hyphenated without spaces per Bellwether style.
Use neutral, evidence-based language and avoid colloquialisms to maintain Bellwether’s tone.

original_text: Michigan has an OBF formula but only uses it to distribute the increase in appropriations in any given fiscal year.
suggested_edit: Michigan has an outcomes-based funding (OBF) formula but uses it only to distribute increases in appropriations in a given fiscal year.
rationale: Clarifies meaning, places only correctly, and spells out abbreviation on first state page per style.
Avoid scare quotes unless quoting a source verbatim; they can imply bias. Bellwether tone favors neutral phrasing.
AP style uses Democratic as the adjective for the party.

issue: Acronym not defined on first mention
rationale: Spell out on first mention per Bellwether exceptions/AP style; improves accessibility for readers.
Add period to end the sentence within the bulleted list; other bullets are full sentences and end with periods. Ensures parallel structure.
Consider comma after high-wage if modifying workforce sectors collectively. However, if “high-wage workforce” is the intended compound modifying sectors, retain original. Flagging for clarity.
AP and Bellwether favor closed form without hyphen.
Spell out state names in narrative text per AP style; postal abbreviations are for datelines and addresses.
Lowercase common nouns unless part of a formal name per AP style.

Check first mention earlier in the document for “In fiscal year (FY) 2023…” per Bellwether exception. If not previously established in this section, consider spelling out on first mention. Flagging for consistency.
Bellwether style: one space after sentences; remove extra space.

original_text: California's funding model balances enrollment & outcomes
suggested_edit: California's funding model balances enrollment and outcomes
rationale: Bellwether style: avoid “&” unless part of a formal name.
Spell out months when not used with a specific date per AP style.
Only capitalize proper nouns; use lowercase for common terms; maintain consistent capitalization within lists.
Spell out acronym on first mention per Bellwether style.

original_text: Performance incentives target industry certifications, transfer success, and workforce-aligned outcomes.
rationale: Actually already includes Oxford comma. No edit needed; removing from list.
Avoid scare quotes unless quoting; maintains neutral tone.

original_text: The association is heavily involved in legislative advocacy and has a PAC named Iowans for a Skilled Workforce
suggested_edit: The association is heavily involved in legislative advocacy and has a PAC, Iowans for a Skilled Workforce
rationale: Add comma for appositive per AP style to improve readability.
Spell out state names in narrative text per AP style.

issue: En dash vs hyphen and numeral style
rationale: Avoid mathematical symbols in narrative lists for clarity; use words per AP style unless space constrained.
No change needed; removing. (Entry left intentionally blank? Recommend ignoring.)
Use AP style abbreviation for titles before names; also curly apostrophe for consistency if typography allows.
Hyphenate compound modifiers before nouns per Bellwether style.

original_text: Mississippi disburses funding based largely on enrollment with a small base allocation; there is no OBF.
suggested_edit: Mississippi disburses funding largely based on enrollment, with a small base allocation; there is no outcomes-based funding (OBF).
rationale: Improve flow and define acronym on first mention on this state page.

original_text: about 25% of funding flowing through the outcomes component.
suggested_edit: about 25% of funding flows through the outcomes component.
rationale: Use active voice and correct verb agreement per Bellwether tone.
AP style uses space on both sides of an ellipsis; maintain readability.
Percent sign is allowed; no change needed. Removing.
Unless it is an official, formal body name, AP style lowercases descriptive committee names. If formal proper name, leave capitalized. Flagging for confirmation.

original_text: Progression: number of students who reach 12, 24, and 36 credit hours each term
suggested_edit: Progression: Number of students who reach 12, 24, and 36 credit hours each term
rationale: Within a list where some items after colons begin with capital letters, ensure consistent capitalization. Alternatively, lowercase all; apply one approach consistently.
Define on first mention within the state section for reader clarity.

original_text: College leaders seem to be satisfied with the distribution formula in place and are unlikely to advocate for change.
suggested_edit: College leaders seem satisfied with the distribution formula and are unlikely to advocate for change.
rationale: Tightens phrasing and removes redundancy in line with Bellwether’s concise tone.

original_text: Gov. Ferguson, who began his term in January 2025, inherited an education plan from former Gov. Inslee, which includes cuts totaling $2.8M from 2025-2027.
suggested_edit: Gov. Ferguson, who began his term in January 2025, inherited an education plan from former Gov. Inslee that includes cuts totaling $2.8 million from 2025 to 2027.
rationale: Replace which with that for essential clause; spell out million; use to for ranges per AP style.
Avoid mathematical symbols in prose for clarity per AP style.
